habitat_description:
Dipodomys ordii is found in habitats with sandy soils in which it can burrow (Maxwell and Brown, 1968; Groves and Keller, 1983; Hoffman et al., 1995; Gitzen et al., 2001; Bender et al., 2010; Heinrichs et al., 2010; Wright and Geluso, 2011).  The species prefers sparsely vegetated, active sand dunes and sandy slopes (Maxwell and Brown, 1968; Root et al., 1999; Kissner, 2009; White, 2009; Bender et al., 2010; Heinrichs et al., 2010). Specific vegetation associations for the species include low cover (Maxwell and Brown, 1968; Kissner, 2009) of: shinnery oak and mesquite grasslands (Johnston, 1956; Best and Hoditschek, 1986; Best et al., 1993; Cramer and Willig, 2002); honey mesquite (Whitford, 1976); rabbitbrush, antelope bitterbrush, and big sagebrush (Groves and Keller, 1983; Sullivan, 1995; Clements and Young, 1996; Gitzen et al., 2001; piñon and juniper woodlands and savanna (Ribble and Samson, 1987; Sullivan, 1995); sagebrush and juniper (Verts et al., 1998); sand sage (Maxwell and Brown, 1968; Fleharty and Navo, 1993; Cramer and Willig, 2002; Wright and Geluso, 2011); saltbush (Root et al., 1999); grasslands with creosotebush (Schroder and Rosenzweig, 1975); grasslands with yucca and opuntia (Maxwell and Brown, 1968; Wright and Geluso, 2011); tarbush and apache plume (Hallet, 1982); bluestem and needle-and-thread grasslands (Maxwell and Brown, 1968; Cramer and Willig, 2002; Wright and Geluso, 2011); and greasewood (Verts et al., 1998).

Ord’s kangaroo rat is found in both burned and unburned habitats (Clements and Young, 1996). The species often thrives in areas where soil has been disturbed (Hoffman et al., 1995), such as: sandy banks and ditches along roadsides (Kaufman and Kaufman, 1982; Kaufman et al., 2000; Gummer and Robertson, 2003; Bender et al., 2010); grazed habitats (Fleharty and Navo, 1993; Kissner, 2009); fallow fields (Kaufman et al., 2000; Gummer and Robertson, 2003); and eroding slopes (Bender et al., 2010). However, anthropogenically-disturbed habitats are often population sinks (Kissner, 2009)

D. ordii avoids riparian forests and exposed channels (Andersen et al., 2000; Kaufman et al., 2000) and prairie sans sandy soils (Ribble and Samson, 1987; Kaufman et al., 2000).

The species’ use of cropland is more nuanced; it has been documented in the edges of agricultural fields (Fleharty and Navo, 1993; Kissner, 2009) and even within wheat fields and clover fields (Kaufman et al., 2000), although it avoids corn fields (Fleharty and Navo, 1993; Wright and Geluso, 2011) and hay fields (Kaufman et al., 2000).
